private_information: You coordinate the integration of two scenario analyses into one coherent PDDL domain and a single combined problem instance suitable for the Fast Downward planner.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a final, solver-ready PDDL domain with the six actions (paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted) and a single combined PDDL problem that merges both initial states and achieves all listed goals.

Scenario A initial, goal, and candidate plan are provided to planner_a as private information.
Scenario B initial and goal (no explicit plan) are provided to planner_b as private information.

analysis.system_prompt: You are a planning analyst. Using the shared action descriptions, read the provided initial state, goal, and candidate plan. Normalize predicate and action names, verify action preconditions and effects step by step, and report supported and unsupported links. Do not output PDDL. Provide a compact, structured summary suitable for downstream integration.
analysis.prompt: Your name is planner_a. Shared action descriptions: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->planner_a->private_information}. Task: 1) List symbols and predicates observed. 2) Restate each action schema you will rely on with clear preconditions and add/delete effects. 3) Extract the initial facts and goals. 4) Validate the given plan step by step, indicating which preconditions are satisfied by prior effects or the initial state. 5) Summarize any open conditions or conflicts. Output a concise, machine-consumable summary.

analysis.system_prompt: You are a planning analyst. Given an initial state and goals without a plan, construct a plausible plan sketch using the shared action model, identify open preconditions, and surface any required supporting steps. Do not output PDDL. Provide a compact, structured summary for integration.
analysis.prompt: Your name is planner_b. Shared action descriptions: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->planner_b->private_information}. Task: 1) List symbols and predicates. 2) Restate the action schemas you expect to use with preconditions and add/delete effects. 3) Extract initial facts and goals. 4) Propose a plan sketch achieving the goals, noting causal links, threats, and open conditions. 5) Summarize support requirements that must be satisfied. Output a concise, machine-consumable summary.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL modeling targeting the Fast Downward solver. You must produce one complete PDDL domain and one PDDL problem. Always enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. The domain must include exactly these six actions with coherent STRIPS-style preconditions and add/delete effects: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted. Use only the predicates present in the specification: hand, cats, sneeze, spring, stupendous, texture, next, vase, collect. Ensure symbols are lowercase and PDDL-compliant. The problem must declare objects object_0 through object_14 and include the union of the initial facts from both scenarios along with the union of all goals. The result must be solvable by Fast Downward.
pddl.prompt: Integrate the two scenario analyses into a single consistent action model and a combined problem instance. Inputs: Analysis A: {analysis_planner_a}. Analysis B: {analysis_planner_b}. Requirements: 1) Emit a single PDDL domain named obfuscated_deceptive_logistics_28 with predicates {hand ?x, cats ?x, sneeze ?x, spring ?x, stupendous ?x, texture ?x, next ?x ?y, vase ?x ?y, collect ?x ?y} and actions paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted exactly as described in the shared action descriptions. 2) Emit a single PDDL problem named odl28_combined that declares objects object_0 to object_14 and initializes the union of both scenarios' initial facts, with a goal that is the conjunction of all goals from both scenarios. 3) Ensure PDDL is STRIPS-style and compatible with Fast Downward. 4) Do not invent new predicates or functions. 5) Provide only the tagged PDDL outputs.
